Things like blind resume review are moreso meant to prevent implicit bias. You may not consciously choose to favor white people over black people when screening candidates, but multiple studies have shown that resumes with “black sounding names” are less likely to be called than resumes with “white sounding names”. So blind resume screening helps to mitigate that bias. Additionally, you may not consciously discriminate against someone with a disability during the interview process, but you may unconsciously look for more flaws in their qualifications vs someone without special needs. So things like implicit bias training and ADA awareness training (both of which would be DEI measures) would help to prevent non compliance with EEO and ADA laws.

DEI (Diversity, Equity, and Inclusion) refers to a broader concept of ensuring fair representation and opportunity for individuals from all backgrounds, including veterans, across various aspects like race, gender, sexual orientation, and socioeconomic status, while "veterans rights" specifically focuses on protecting and advocating for the legal entitlements and benefits earned by individuals who have served in the military, addressing issues related to their service experience and potential challenges upon returning to civilian life; essentially, veteran status is considered one facet within the larger DEI framework.

A person who disagrees with DEI initiatives is not racist or exclusionary. DEI, as currently practiced, can inadvertently lead to reverse discrimination, where individuals from majority groups are excluded in favor of underrepresented groups to meet a quota, necessarily undermining merit-based systems. DEI often focuses on certain aspects of diversity while neglecting others, like socioeconomic background or neurodiversity, and ideology which result in exclusion.

Thank you Costco for creating a wonderful workplace that supports merit and while having a strong stance Diversity and inclusion. It’s called a “hand up and not a hand out.” Both can be true.

Also, for anyone that thinks DEI means that if two candidates are completely equal, you have to choose the minority, I’m sorry but you don’t understand how hiring and candidate selection works. People are not economic units. There’s no perfect way to evaluate them and there is NEVER a situation where two candidates are completely equal in skill level, education, experience, interview ability, personality, etc. It just doesn’t happen. There may be times when you’ve got two good candidates that might be tough to choose between, but that doesn’t mean you go with the minority. In those cases, HR generally works with the hiring manager to decide which qualifications would be the most important. Maybe for a sales role, you have to great candidates but one is better at phone sales and one seems to be better at door to door sales so you choose based on which is most prevalent in the company.

I have a friend who is DEI "certified". It only required a short course online and then she was "certified". Now she does DEI training, sensitivity trainings for businesses. DEI is NOT merit based hiring and that makes it very dangerous. Most DEI hires are based upon race, sexual orientation, etc...

I’ve worked in talent acquisition and hiring for my entire career. I have never had a company ask that I consider someone’s race, orientation, or gender when making a hiring decision. There is NO evidence to support that DEI initiatives lead to discriminatory hiring.
how many companies were involved in your research to reach this conclusion?

Joe- At Costco, we make every effort to provide a wide variety of products at all of our warehouses, but each of our selected items must demonstrate high enough sales for us to continue to stock it. We also have to take into account whether our suppliers have enough merchandise available and stock accordingly. Nevertheless, Costco takes inventory requests from members very seriously, and I've forwarded your interest in this product to the appropriate department. We also invite you to copy and paste the following link https://www.costco.com/WarehouseFeedback.html, which will allow you to share your suggestions of products you would like to see available. Thanks for posting! -Ernie

A person who disagrees with DEI initiatives is not racist or exclusionary. DEI, as currently practiced, can inadvertently lead to reverse discrimination, where individuals from majority groups are excluded in favor of underrepresented groups to meet a quota, necessarily undermining merit-based systems. DEI often focuses on certain aspects of diversity while neglecting others, like socioeconomic background or neurodiversity, and ideology which result in exclusion.

diversity, equity and inclusion, I don’t see merit there do you? No one should have to check any boxes to hire or fire. No quotas. By the way the Supreme Court “ The Court ruled that race conscious college admission policies aimed at maintaining racially diverse student bodies violated the Equal Protection Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment.”The only thing that matters is their qualifications. Judge by the content of character not to color of your skin.

Also, for anyone that thinks DEI means that if two candidates are completely equal, you have to choose the minority, I’m sorry but you don’t understand how hiring and candidate selection works. People are not economic units. There’s no perfect way to evaluate them and there is NEVER a situation where two candidates are completely equal in skill level, education, experience, interview ability, personality, etc. It just doesn’t happen. There may be times when you’ve got two good candidates that might be tough to choose between, but that doesn’t mean you go with the minority. In those cases, HR generally works with the hiring manager to decide which qualifications would be the most important. Maybe for a sales role, you have to great candidates but one is better at phone sales and one seems to be better at door to door sales so you choose based on which is most prevalent in the company.
